head.title: The temperature dependent behaviour of surface states in ferromagnetic semiconductors

article.h1: The temperature dependent behaviour of surface states in ferromagnetic semiconductors

div.p: We present a model calculation for the temperature dependent behaviour of surface states on a ferromagnetic local-moment film. The film is described within the s-f model featuring local magnetic moments being exchange coupled to the itinerant conduction electrons. The surface states are generated by modifying the hopping in the vicinity of the surface of the film. In the calculation for the temperature dependent behaviour of the surface states we are able to reproduce both Stoner-like and spin-mixing behaviour in agreement with recent (inverse) photoemission data on the temperature dependent behaviour of a Gd(0001) surface state.

In the recent past many theoretical and experimental research works have been focussed on the intriguing properties of rare earth metals and their compounds. On the exeperimental side, this interest was aroused after Weller et al.Â reported on the existence of the magnetically ordered Gd(0001) surface at temperatures where the bulk Gadolinium is paramagnetic [2]. Since then, a variety of different experimental techniques has been applied to the problem by different groups yielding values of the surface Curie temperature enhancement, Î”â¢TC=TCâ¢(surface)-TCâ¢(bulk)Î”subscriptğ‘‡ğ¶subscriptğ‘‡ğ¶surfacesubscriptğ‘‡ğ¶bulkDelta italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( surface CLOSE:) ADDOP:minus italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( bulk CLOSE:)\Delta T_{C}=T_{C}({\rm surface})-T_{C}({\rm bulk}), between 17K and 60K [3, 4, 5]. Contrary to the groups cited above Donath et al.Â using spin-resolved photoemission did not find any indication for an enhanced Curie temperature at the Gd(0001) surface [6], fueling the controversial discussion.

Concerning the interplay between electronic structure and exceptional magnetic properties at the Gadolinium surface a Gd(0001) surface state [7, 8] is believed to play a crucial role and its temperature dependent behaviour has been discussed intensely [6, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13, 14]. Recently, the investigation of the correlation between strain induced alteration of the surface electronic structure and enhanced magnetization in Gd films has been addressed by a number of experimental works [14, 15, 16, 17]. A thorough account on the surface magnetism and the surface electronic structure of the lanthanides has been given by Dowben et al. [18].

Rare-earth materials are so-called local-moment systems, i.e.Â the magnetic moment stems from the partially filled 4f-shell of the rare-earth atom being strictly localized at the ion site. Thus the magnetic properties of these materials are determined by the localized magnetic moments. On the other hand, the electronic properties like electrical conductivity are borne by itinerant electrons in rather broad conduction bands, e.g.Â 6s, 5d for Gd. Many of the characteristics of local-moment systems can be attributed to a correlation between the localized moments and the itinerant conduction electrons. For this situation the s-f model has been proven to be an adequate description. In this model, the correlation between localized moments and conduction electrons is represented by an intraatomic exchange interaction.

div.p: Taking into account Eqs.Â (12)-(The temperature dependent behaviour of surface states in ferromagnetic semiconductors), we have now a closed system of equations, provided that the f-spin correlation functions appearing in Eqs.Â (The temperature dependent behaviour of surface states in ferromagnetic semiconductors) are known.

These can be evaluted by considering the magnetic subsystem, according to the Hamiltonian â„‹fsubscriptâ„‹ğ‘“caligraphic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\cal H}_{f} (Eq.Â (3)). For all what concerns us in this paper it is only interesting that, employing an RPA-type decoupling, a solution of the magnetic subsystem can be found[19] and that it gives us all the necessary layer-dependent f-spin correlation functions as a function of temperature from T=0ğ‘‡0italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0T=0 to the Curie temperature, T=TCğ‘‡subscriptğ‘‡ğ¶italic-T RELOP:equals italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT=T_{C} [20]. Mediated by Eqs.Â (14)-(The temperature dependent behaviour of surface states in ferromagnetic semiconductors), the f-spin correlation functions contain the whole temperature dependence of the electronic subsystem.

To briefly recall the main results presented in our previous paper [20], Fig.Â 1 shows the density of states of a s.c.-(100) double layer for different s-f interactions and different temperatures. In the case of ferromagnetic saturation, T=0ğ‘‡0italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0T=0, we see that for the spin-â†‘â†‘ARROW:uparrow\uparrow electron the density of states of the free case J=0ğ½0italic-J RELOP:equals NUMBER:0J=0 (dotted line) is just rigidly shifted when the interaction is switched on. This is due to the impossibility of the spin-â†‘â†‘ARROW:uparrow\uparrow electron to exchange its spin with the perfectly alligned local-moment system. For the spin-â†“â†“ARROW:downarrow\downarrow electron in the case of small s-f exchange coupling, J>0ğ½0italic-J RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:0J>0, a slight deformation of the free density of states sets in. For intermediate and strong couplings (Jâª†0.2greater-than-or-approximately-equalsğ½0.2italic-J RELOP:greater-than-or-approximately-equals NUMBER:0.2J\gtrapprox 0.2), the density of states splits into two parts, corresponding to two different spin exchange processes between the spin-â†“â†“ARROW:downarrow\downarrow electron and the localized f-spin system. The higher energetic part represents a polarization of the immediate spin neighbourhood of the electron due to the repeated emission and reabsorption of magnons. The corresponding polaron-like quasiparticle is called the magnetic polaron. The low-energetic part of the spectrum is a scattering band which can be explained by the simple emission of a magnon by the spin-â†“â†“ARROW:downarrow\downarrow electron without reabsorption, but necessarily connected with a spin flip of the electron [24].

For T>0ğ‘‡0italic-T RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:0T>0 we see in Fig.Â 1 that with increasing temperature for the spin-â†“â†“ARROW:downarrow\downarrow electron spectral weight is transferred from the high-energetic polaron peak to the low-energetic scattering peak. On the other hand, for the spin-â†‘â†‘ARROW:uparrow\uparrow electron we have the effect that for finite temperatures an additional peak rises at the high energetic side of the spectrum. This rise with increasing temperature is fueled by the loss of spectral weight on the low-energetic peak. The high-energetic peak simply represents the ability of the spin-â†‘â†‘ARROW:uparrow\uparrow electron to exchange its spin with a not perfectly aligned local-moment system, T>0ğ‘‡0italic-T RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:0T>0 [20]. As a result of the shifts of spectral weight occuring for both, the spin-â†‘â†‘ARROW:uparrow\uparrow and spin-â†“â†“ARROW:downarrow\downarrow spectra, the spectra for the two spin directions approach each other with increasing temperature. In the limiting case of Tâ†’TCâ†’ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘‡ğ¶italic-T ARROW:rightarrow italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT\rightarrow T_{C} the system has eventually lost its ability to distinguish between the two possible spin directions because of the loss of magnetization of the underlying local-moment system. Hence, for T=TCğ‘‡subscriptğ‘‡ğ¶italic-T RELOP:equals italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT=T_{C} the densities of states of the spin-â†“â†“ARROW:downarrow\downarrow and the spin-â†‘â†‘ARROW:uparrow\uparrow electron are equal. Another feature which can be seen in Fig.Â 1 is that while the positions of the quasiparticle subbands stays pretty much the same we observe a narrowing of the bands with increasing temperature. This can especially well be seen for the case of temperature evolvement of spectrum of the spin-â†“â†“ARROW:downarrow\downarrow electron for the case of J=0.2ğ½0.2italic-J RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.2J=0.2. Whereas the scattering band and the polaron band are, for the case of T=0ğ‘‡0italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0T=0, still merged, in the case of T=TCğ‘‡subscriptğ‘‡ğ¶italic-T RELOP:equals italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT=T_{C} both bands are clearly separated.

In this paper we are interested in surface states and their temperature dependent behaviour. Surface states occur in the spectral density at energies different from the bulk energies and are localized in the vicinity of the surface of a crystal. The theory presented above is applied to a s.c. film consisting of nğ‘›italic-nn layers oriented parallel to the (100)-surface as drawn schematically in Fig.Â 2.

When the temperature is increased, the spectral weight of these contributions is altered until for T=TCğ‘‡subscriptğ‘‡ğ¶italic-T RELOP:equals italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT=T_{C} for each peak the spin-â†“â†“ARROW:downarrow\downarrow and the spin-â†‘â†‘ARROW:uparrow\uparrow contributions have the same spectral weights.

In being able to reproduce both Stoner-like and spin-mixing behaviour, depending on the variation of the hopping and the position in the Brillouin zone, our model calculations are in harmony with more recent (inverse) photoemission studies on Gd(0001) films which abandoned the grasp of earlier works that the temperature dependent behaviour of the Gd(0001) surface state has to be either Stoner-like or of spin-mixing type [12, 13]. Especially, it has been shown here that for certain parameters it is possible to observe both kinds of behaviour at the same time (see Fig.Â 5). This feature of our model calculation seems to be in strong agreement with a scenario proposed by Donath and Gubanka [12].
